meanings.definition: To prevent or constrain (someone) from breathing freely; suffocate.
meanings.sent1: The heavy smoke seemed to stifle him as he struggled to catch his breath.
meanings.sent2: She felt like the tight scarf was going to stifle her if she didn't loosen it.
meanings.sent3: Trying to talk with a mouthful of marshmallows made him sound like he was trying to stifle a laugh.
meanings.sent4: The silence in the room was so thick, it seemed to stifle any sound from escaping.
meanings.sent5: The oppressive heat seemed to stifle all life out of the once vibrant garden.

meanings.definition: To restrain (a reaction) or stop oneself acting on (an emotion).
meanings.sent1: She had to stifle a gasp when she saw the surprise party waiting for her.
meanings.sent2: He had to stifle his anger and calmly explain the situation to avoid a fight.
meanings.sent3: Trying to stifle a sneeze by pinching his nose only made him look like a confused rabbit.
meanings.sent4: The excitement was so overwhelming, she could barely stifle her squeals of joy.
meanings.sent5: The urge to dance was so strong, she could hardly stifle her happy feet from tapping along.

meanings.sent1: He tried to stifle a yawn during the boring presentation.
meanings.sent2: She couldn't stifle her laughter when she saw the puppy chasing its tail.
meanings.sent3: The urge to sing along was hard to stifle as her favorite song played on the radio.
meanings.sent4: The guilt was so overwhelming, she could barely stifle her tears.
meanings.sent5: The excitement bubbled inside her, impossible to stifle, as she waited for the results.
